1. A 14-year-old male presents with progressively worsening unsteady gait and frequent falls over the past three years, along with stiffness in his legs. His parents report difficulties with fine motor skills, such as writing and buttoning clothes, and recent onset of slurred speech. On examination, he exhibits truncal ataxia, increased tone in the lower limbs, hyperreflexia, and bilateral Babinski signs. There is no history of cognitive decline or seizures. Family history reveals a consanguineous marriage, but no known neurological disorders. Brain MRI shows mild cerebellar atrophy without other abnormalities. Genetic testing confirms a pathogenic mutation in the SYNE1 gene associated with autosomal recessive spastic ataxia 2. Supportive management including physical therapy and symptom-targeted medications is initiated.
